answers.author: Deborah Bond
answers.text:
We did not change our fund balance policies but we are clarifying how to rebuild our rainy day reserve for the general fund now that we used it.  It was a part of the policy that had not been fully addressed in the past.
We are also looking at our economic development policies to position ourselves better once the recovery does begin.
Also we are looking at extending the investment maturities from 3 yrs to 5 yrs to take advantage of the yield on longer term investments.  We will only do this for about 25% of the entire portfolio.
We have not as yet started on what "to add back first" once we do see improvement...we are still into cutting unfortunately.

answers.text:
The City of Peoria AZ's staff is reviewing our City's Principles of Sound Financial Management for a number of reasons, in part because of the economic conditions we've experienced over the past two years. We'll be taking a number of proposed changes to the Council in a study session in the next month or so. I'll be happy to share them when they are finalized.

answers.author: Mark Achen
answers.text:
During the energy bust that decimated Grand Junction, Colorado, in the mid-1980's to early 1990's, our strategy for use of our fairly substantial capital improvement reserves was altered.  We called it the "half (actually one-third) life" policy.  Only one-third of these reserves were to be budgeted for capital projects in any year.  Each year only one-third of what remained from the previous year was to be committed.  The notion was to assure some level, although declining, of capital spending each year, keep some "powder" dry for emergencies and the uncertain economic conditions.  Along with our long range cip, it discouraged use for operating purposes, kept at least a modest pipeline of capital resources while we awaited an economic turn-around and helped win subsequent voter approval of a dedicated capital revenue stream (sales tax).  That downturn lasted four years to the bottom and another four-plus years bouncing along the bottom before any significant growth in revenues.

author: Pamela Muse
text:
The City of Flagstaff, AZ is interested in how other municipalities have changed/updated their financial policies in response to the recession.  For ex:  

Decreased (or suspended) fund balance/reserve requirements?  
Changed bonding/borrowing constraints?  
Changed investment strategy?  
Changed revenue strategy?  

In addition - I'm interested in knowing - as you come out of recession - have you/are you developed financial 'policy' of how you would spend 'recovery' revenues:  

Reinstate programs/staff that had been cut?  
Compensation catch up?  
New service?

Thanks for your help; I look forward to hearing from you.  
Barbara Goodrich  
Management Services Director  
City of Flagstaff, AZ  
(928) 913-3201   
bgoodric@flagstaffaz.gov
title: Updated Financial Policies in Response to Recession
